answers.answer: I am not going to say that nurse practitioner are not good.  Most of the nurse practitioner are pretty good they are very detailed. They do an awesome job.  BUT if you have this kind of problems you better see an OBGYN.  With this issues most of the GPs' would refer us to a Specialist.Take care and hope you find good OBGYN to take care of you.

question: Hi, my name is Brittany.  I am seeking a second opinion in regards to my reproductive system.  I am 23 years old and I did not start my menstrual cycle until the age of 17.  Ever since then, they have been extremely irregular and it is not uncommon for me to go 7 or 8 months without having one.  Right now, I am going on 8 months without having a cycle.  I went to the nurse practitioner in my town and they ran blood tests and did an internal and external ultrasound and everything checked out fine, but from what she said, my follicles in my ovaries were immature and the lining of my uterus was extremely thin and showing no signs of having a cycle or ovulating.  She said that although my test results were "inconclusive", she thinks I have Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome.  I have researched this extensively and I strongly disagree because I do not have any of the symptoms that go along with that.  She wanted to put me on a medication for diabetes patients and I just can't do that when I strongly believe she has misdiagnosed me.  I am looking for a second opinion.  Has anyone else had any experience with this?
title: In search of a second opinion...
